column4: yeah you shouldn't do that, have you tried going into Synaptic and searching and removing all vmware packages?
I have, and all vmware packages are not installed
or you could figure out what package an installed file is from with dpkg -S path/to/file
I can't seem to find the file of the program itself. There are so many vmware files to hunt through
how about the ones in /etc/init.d or /usr/lib you mentioned?
The ones I am trying give the result of "dpkg: *filename* not found
Should I just delete the files?  =/
perhaps, did you install using apt-get? what is the file name in /etc/init.d/ ?
I don't remember how I installed it! I don't think it was with apt-get, but I'm not sure. The init.d file is called "vmware"
if you install things other ways it can be difficult to remove completey, however you can prevent it from starting by just doing: sudo update-rc.d vmware remove
That would be great. I was mostly concerned with the five seconds or so it was adding to my boot time
update-rc.d: /etc/init.d/vmware exists during rc.d purge (use -f to force)

update-rc.d: /etc/init.d/vmware exists during rc.d purge (use -f to force)
2008-12-29T07:49:00.000Z	Susie
Should I force it or would that be harmful?
go ahead and add the -f option, sudo update-rc.d -f vmware remove
all this does is remove the links to /etc/init.d/vmware in the /etc/rc*.d/ directories which cause it to start, you can always recreate them
That seemed to do it. Thanks. :)
